discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B. Multicast traffic is increased throughout the network.

When multiple wireless controllers are part of the same CAPWAP (Control and Provisioning of Wireless Access Points) multicast group, the multicast traffic used for communication between the controllers and access points (APs) will increase. This is because each controller in the group will send and receive multicast packets to manage and communicate with the APs, leading to higher multicast traffic across the network.

Selected Answer: B
The correct answer is B. Multicast traffic is increased throughout the network.

When multiple wireless controllers are in the same CAPWAP (Control and Provisioning of Wireless Access Points) multicast group, the multicast traffic associated with CAPWAP communication between access points and controllers increases. This is because the controllers use multicast to exchange control and provisioning information with the access points.

choices.A: Multicast packets are rate-limited to 128 kbps.
choices.B: Multicast traffic is increased throughout the network.
choices.C: ACL filtering are used on the first hop router on all VLANs.

questions.question_text: What is an indication of having multiple wireless controllers within the same CAPWAP multicast group?

//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An engineer implemented a CPU ACL on the controller, and now the Web Authentication Redirect page is not working. What must be changed for the redirect page to work?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
- Therefore, if CPU ACLs are enabled in the WLC, an allow rule for the virtual interface IP is required (In ANY direction) in these conditions:
 - When the CPU ACL does not have an allow ALL rule for both directions.
 - When there exists an allow ALL rule, but there also exists a DENY rule for port 443 or 80 of higher precedence.

- The allow rule for the virtual IP must be for TCP protocol and port 80 if secureweb is disabled, or port 443 if secureweb is enabled. This is needed in order to allow the access of the client to the virtual interface IP address post successful authentication when CPU ACLs are in place.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/wireless/5500-series-wireless-controllers/108501-webauth-tshoot.html

Selected Answer: B
B is correct one

Selected Answer: B
Looking at the exhibit, ACL named "mgmt" is applied as CPU ACL, and line Seq 3 is permitting traffic to the WLC Virtual IP ADD already (so option C is not correct, it is a redundant statement). What that line needs is to be amended, to both directions.

Selected Answer: B
B is correct one

A is correct - Option B is not the correct answer because the permit statement for 192.0.2.100 being in both directions does not directly address the issue of the Web Authentication Redirect page not working.

Option C is also not the correct answer because the Web Authentication Redirect does not need to be configured on the CPU ACLs. The issue lies with the CPU ACL implementation and not the configuration of the Web Authentication Redirect itself.

Selected Answer: A

 - When the CPU ACL does not have an allow ALL rule for both directions.
 - When there exists an allow ALL rule, but there also exists a DENY rule for port 443 or 80 of higher precedence.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/wireless/5500-series-wireless-controllers/108501-webauth-tshoot.html

Selected Answer: C
C is correct. From https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/wireless/controller/8-2/config-guide/b_cg82/b_cg82_chapter_01110.html.
When you apply CPU ACLs on a Cisco 5508 WLC or a Cisco WiSM2, you must permit traffic towards the virtual interface IP address for web authentication. The packet direction does not have any significance, it is always ‘Any’.

comments.content: So you mean B and not C

choices.B: The permit statement for 192.0.2.100 must be in both directions.
choices.A: The permit statement must be directed to the controller management address.
choices.C: The Web Authentication Redirect must be configured on the CPU ACLs.
choices.D: The Web Authentication Redirect must be HTTP.

choices.A: Enable a unique NAS-ID for the AP group.
choices.D: Enable an ACL on the router that serves the VLAN or subnet.

questions.question_text: Clients on access points within an AP group are not receiving multicast traffic after roaming to another AP within the AP group. Which action maintains multicast connectivity?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
When clients on access points (APs) within an AP group are not receiving multicast traffic after roaming to another AP within the same group, the issue is often related to how multicast traffic is being handled in the network. IGMP snooping is a feature that helps manage multicast traffic more efficiently by ensuring that multicast packets are only forwarded to the ports (or APs) where there are interested receivers.

Selected Answer: A
To preserve the QoS marking sent by the Cisco Jabber software running on PC1, the DSCP (Differentiated Services Code Point) value must be trusted on port Fa 0/6. Cisco Jabber, like many modern applications, uses DSCP to mark IP packets for QoS prioritization at Layer 3. Trusting the DSCP value ensures that the QoS markings set by the application are preserved as traffic traverses the network.

Explanation of the options:
A. DSCP: This is correct. DSCP is a Layer 3 marking used in the IP header for QoS prioritization. Trusting DSCP ensures that the markings set by Cisco Jabber are preserved.

B. 802.1p: This is a Layer 2 marking used in the Ethernet frame for QoS prioritization. It is not relevant for preserving markings set by Cisco Jabber, which operates at Layer 3.

C. CoS (Class of Service): This is another term for 802.1p, which is a Layer 2 marking. It is not applicable for preserving Layer 3 DSCP markings.

D. IP precedence: This is an older Layer 3 QoS marking method that has been largely replaced by DSCP. It is not the correct choice for modern applications like Cisco Jabber.

An engineer must enable AVC on a Cisco Catalyst 9800 WLC and send the NetFlow data to a NetFlow collector. What must be configured on the controller with the IP address and port number of the NetFlow collector?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
To enable Application Visibility and Control (AVC) on a Cisco Catalyst 9800 Wireless LAN Controller (WLC) and send NetFlow data to a NetFlow collector, you must configure a flow exporter. The flow exporter specifies the IP address and port number of the NetFlow collector where the data will be sent.

Explanation of the options:
A. flow exporter: This is correct. The flow exporter is used to define the destination (IP address and port) of the NetFlow collector.

B. flow policy: A flow policy is used to define actions (e.g., marking, policing) applied to traffic flows, but it does not specify the NetFlow collector's IP address and port.

C. flow monitor: A flow monitor is used to associate a flow record with an interface to collect traffic data, but it does not specify the NetFlow collector's IP address and port.

D. flow record: A flow record defines the specific traffic attributes (e.g., source IP, destination IP, protocol) to be collected, but it does not specify the NetFlow collector's IP address and port.
